title: Introduction to Line Management
headline: A free online course to help equip management professionals with team and self-management skills.
description: This practical course will explore how a line manager can achieve specific organisational and functional goals. All aspects of coaching, mentoring, talent management, effective communication and performance appraisal will enhance your team management skills. You will also learn self-management and leadership skills to manage stress, time and conflict. Those looking to pursue a career in management will benefit from this wealth of information.

courseDescription:
All industries need efficient line managers at strategic and functional levels to manage employees and develop teams. In this course, you will begin by understanding the importance and scope of line management. What does a line manager do? What are the developmental approaches that a line manager can use? You will learn about coaching, mentoring, talent management and performance appraisal while understanding the importance of motivation and communication in the organisational context.

Can you regulate or control your thoughts, behaviour and action? You can if you acquire self-management skills. You will learn to quickly identify the stressors around you and manage stress to perform your professional duties. Prioritising your tasks helps in managing time. You will learn about the Pareto Principle and other time management tips. The section on employee relations and human resource management dynamics will help develop your leadership skills.

Finally, you will dive into the details of conflict and anger management. The conflict resolution techniques offer a valuable template for managing confrontations in teams. A line manager should be aware of employment law, its nature and the statutory employment rights to be effective. The skills taught in this course are in demand because our economy depends on smooth operations in any industry. You can enrol in this online course today to move a step up in your chosen career.

Start Course Now
certificateDetail:
All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this certificate course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this certificate course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison certificate is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital certificate: a downloadable certificate in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • certificate: a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked certificate, posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed certificate: a physical version of your officially branded and security marked certificate in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.
Start Course Now

All certificate are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison certificate, please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison certificate, you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. For more details on our certificate pricing, please visit our Pricing Page

modules.name: Module
modules.description: What skills do first-line managers need? This module will cover five essential responsibilities of a line manager. You will learn the importance of coaching and mentoring as well as the need for supervising, motivating or counselling. You will also explore how to implement talent management and the key factors in performance appraisal management.

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In addition to maintaining relations, line managers should have the self-management skills to control and work around their emotions. In this module, you will learn about managing stress and time. Before learning about managing conflict and employment laws, you will also get acquainted with employee relationships and human resource management.
topics: Learning Outcomes: Self Management and Relationship Skills
Lesson Summary Self Management and Relationship Skills

slides:
• Learning Outcomes

  • Having completed this module you will be able to:
    • Describe the qualities and primary duties of a line manager.
    • Explain the effectiveness of coaching and mentoring.
    • Identify the needs for supervising, motivating or counselling.
    • Analyse and implement talent management in an organisation.
    • Recognise the role of practical communication skills in line management.
    • Outline the key factors in performance appraisal management.

  • Lesson Summary

  • The key points that were covered in this module are:
    • Line management refers to the administrative management of a business's employees. This style encompasses employee administration, involving responsibilities like performance reviews and disciplinary matters.
    • The line manager position is often referred to as the first level of management to whom non-managerial employees report. Their responsibilities have shifted from traditional supervisory duties to being implementers of HR practices.
    • Essential skills for line managers include- effective communication, active listening, the ability to prioritise and delegate tasks, leadership, and organisation.
    • Line managers have limited skills and competencies in HRM due to a lack of training.
    • The ten values of successful staff coaching include clarity, supportiveness, confidence building, mutuality, perspective, risk, patience, involvement, confidentiality, and respect.
    • An excellent coach focuses on the team's performance, realising that the whole is greater than any of its parts. The steps for a coaching session essentially concentrate on communication, honouring your associate, and establishing a continuous relationship of support.
    • Mentoring is about doing and understanding.

  • Learning Outcomes

  • Having completed this module you will be able to:
    • Relate the stress management issues within the organisational context.
    • Recall the elements of time management.
    • List the tips for managing time.
    • Indicate how to implement good employee relations in an organisation.
    • Describe ways and means to handle conflict.
    • Summarise the primary forms of employment law.

  • Employment Law for Line Managers

  • Employment Law for Line Managers

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Employment Law for Line Managers

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Lesson Summary

  • The key points that were covered in this module are:
    • Stress is defined as a condition where a consequence of events places high levels of physical and psychological demand on individuals.
    • The stress response begins with a stressor, or demand, which serves as the trigger for a series of mind-body activities. The stressor is the physical or psychological stimulus to which an individual responds.
    • When confronted with demand or stressors, the stress response is the generalised, patterned, unconscious mobilisation of the body’s natural energy resources.
    • Stress in an organisation is of concern to both managers and professionals because of the costs associated with job strain and job distress.
    • Lack of control over and uncertainty about aspects of the psychosocial and physical work environments in industrialised nations are significant sources of job stress.
    • High-strain jobs, characterised by high job demands and low employee control, have significantly higher rates of distress, manifested in diseases such as myocardial infarction.
    • Good time management is an essential skill that can help you work more efficiently under pressure and ultimately achieve your career goals.
    • Time management consists of several aspects: Effective planning, Setting goals and objectives, Setting deadlines, Delegation of responsibilities, and Spending the right amount of time on an activity.
